sections.title: What date did your business first commercially exploit aggregates?

fields.label: What date did your business first commercially exploit aggregates?
fields.helpText: Enter the date you first commercially exploited aggregate or formally planned to. For example 06 04 2018

fields.label: What counts as commercially exploiting aggregates?
fields.infoText:
Aggregate is commercially exploited when it is exploited for the advancement or benefit of business. For example when it is:

•	subject to an agreement to supply (such as  
        a contract)

•	used for construction purposes

•	mixed with anything other than water, 
        except in permitted circumstances

•	removed from:

it's originating site

a connected site that is registered under 
the same name

 a site where it had been intended to apply an exempt process but this was not applied

Full details are given in Notice AGL1.

sections.title: Do you expect any of your commercial activity to be exempt or relieved from the levy?

fields.label: What activities are exempt or relieved from the levy?
fields.infoText:
Commercial activities involving the following substances (when they make up more than half of the total material) are exempt from the levy:

• coal, lignite, clay, slate, soil or vegetable or other organic matter

• blocks of stone (dimension stone) and limestone for the production of lime or cement

• certain industrial minerals (such as metal ores, gypsum, fluorspar)

• waste that’s wholly from industrial combustion processes or the smelting or refining of metals

• drill cuttings (in permitted circumstances) and waste from certain processes such as highways or railways excavation, navigational dredging and building construction (in permitted circumstances)

Commercial activities involving the following aggregates are relieved from the levy:

• any aggregate used in prescribed industrial or agricultural processes (such as glass manufacture, fertiliser production)

• aggregate that has previously borne levy and to which an exempt process is applied

Full details of the exemptions and reliefs are given in Notices AGL1 and AGL2.
